properties.description: Work started shortly after conquest in the 1st century BC then lasted until the 3rd century AD. Corta de Covas opencast, 430 m in length, 2.3 million m³ removed. properties.description: A road leading to town and fort and workings has been identified. An imperial freedman's gravestone indicates imperial control of mines. Inscribed lead ingots have been excavated with the names of companies or of the transporters of the lead. The emperors Claudius, Nero, and Vespasian are named on lead ingots.

properties.locationdatasource: Google Earth
properties.description: A Roman gold mine located in Pumsaint, Wales operating from the first through the third century. The nearby fort (2 ha) probably oversaw the mining operation and suggest imperial control of the mines. However civilian contractors probably worked the mines later. A large hydraulic system was set up with multiple tanks and 5 aqueducts, one over 11 km in length, for exploiting the opencast pits. Underground mining also took place to considerable depths and pieces of a water wheel used to drain the mines were found in the 1930’s. Bath house and workshops found near the mines. The Carreg Pumpsaint is an anvil stone from a Roman ore-crushing machine, located next to a heap of crushed ore slimes, and a wheel-race fed from a dammed pond.

Roads, settlements and forts created by specialist contractors brought in after military establishment. 33 denarii of Antonius Pius and coins of Constantine were found. Roads and track ways leading between Great Orme and the Chester (Deva) fort.
properties.notes: See for list of finds: http://shropshirehistory.com/other/llanymynech.htm

properties.description: Gallery extending nearly 120 m underground. Roman counterfeit coinage produced here.

properties.description: The creation of roads, settlements and forts suggests specialist contractors brought in after establishment by military. However there is evidence that civilians were involved in the mining.
Coins of Antoninus Pius found as well as Hadrianic ingots have been found.

properties.description: Vertical shaft c. 50 ft deep; Main Passage 300 ft long and between 18 in and 20 ft high, and chambers full of miners' deads. Five possible openings to the surface including the shaft through which the mine was discovered in 1965. Two late 3rd-c. coins and counterfeiting material found around a hearth that post-dates the abandonment of the mine.

properties.description: Work started shortly after conquest in the 1st century BC then lasted until the 3rd century AD. Corta de Ribeirinha, large opencast 370 m in length, 2.5 million m³ removed,  Traces of firesetting at the base. Underground galleries for ore extraction, and prospection. Peak extraction dates to first half of second century AD. Anvil stones from Roman water-powered ore-crushing machines have been found.
properties.notes: Ore-crushing anvils from machines

properties.description: Extraction started at Tharsis in the Iron Age, circa 2500 BC. The zenith of production was under Trajan but coins which have been found suggest mining could have continued until AD 350. The site has large slag piles and an estimated 4,000,000 tonnes of slag were produced. Other finds include remains of a water wheel with a rope still attached. After the Visigoths invaded the difficulty in draining the mine may have made it unworkable and been the cause of its closure.

properties.locationdatasource: Google Earth
properties.description: Traces of opencast mining and extensive smelting slag predating 18th-c. exploitation. Spread of smelting slag dated by radiocarbon dates of 60 BC to AD 90 and AD 20-220 (95.4%).  Roman ore crushing anvil, Carreg Angharad Fychan, nearby. Roman fort 200 m from mine.
